Claims.expr: the number of triples (A, B, C) such that A, B, C ⊆ {1,2,3,…,8}, |A|=|B|=|C|=4, |A∩B|=|B∩C|=|C∩A|=2
cases N=0, N=1, N=2 are exhaustive and disjoint
the number of such triples is 45360
N = # ways to assemble 2 red and 25 white unit cubes into 3x3x3 with red visible on exactly 4 faces
3x3x3 cube: 8 corners (3 faces each), 12 edge-middles (2 faces each), 6 face-centers (1 face each), 1 internal (0 faces)
red cubes identical; configurations by positions; rotations/reflections distinct
|F1 ∪ F2| = |F1| + |F2| - |F1 ∩ F2| for faces F1, F2 covered by each red
both corners valid if adjacent: 3 + 3 - 2 = 4 faces
each edge gives 1 adjacent corner pair
corner + edge: valid if share 1 face: 3 + 2 - 1 = 4
each face has 4 edges; 2 adjacent to corner (share 2), 2 share 1
corner + face-center: valid if share 0 faces: 3 + 1 - 0 = 4
two edges: valid if share 0 faces: 2 + 2 - 0 = 4
each edge on 2 faces, each face 4 edges, union 4 + 4 - 1 = 7 edges sharing face incl self
cases with internal or non-adjacent corners: ≠ 4 faces
N = # ways to assemble (|R7| + 0) red and 25 white unit cubes into 3x3x3 with red visible on exactly 4 faces
Find all positive integers n such that exists bijective g: Z/nZ -> Z/nZ with forall k=0 to 100, map x |-> g(x) + k x is bijective on Z/nZ
Bijective g: Z/nZ -> Z/nZ is a permutation
Functions f_k(x) = g(x) + k x for k = 0,1,...,100
If gcd(n, 101!) = 1 then exists such g
Multiplication by m on Z/nZ is bijective iff gcd(m, n) = 1
gcd(n, 101!) = 1 implies gcd(k+1, n) = 1 for k=0 to 100
Thus all f_k bijective if gcd(n, 101!) = 1
If gcd(n, 101!) > 1 then no such g
gcd(n, 101!) > 1 implies exists prime p <= 101 with p | n
Such g exists implies f_k bijective mod p for all k=0 to 100
Let bar{g} = g mod p, bijective on F_p = Z/pZ
{k mod p | k=0 to 100} = F_p since 101 >= p
f_k mod p depends only on bar{k} = k mod p
For every c in F_p, exists k=0 to 100 with bar{k}=c and f_k bijective mod p
Thus h_c(x) = bar{g}(x) + c x bijective on F_p for all c in F_p
For any bijective bar{g} on F_p (p>=2), exists x ≠ y in F_p with s = (bar{g}(x) - bar{g}(y)) / (x - y) in F_p
For c = s, h_c(x) = h_c(y) so h_c not injective
Thus no bijective bar{g} with h_c bijective for all c in F_p
Contradiction, so no such g on Z/nZ if p | n, p<=101
All positive integers n with gcd(n, 101!) = 1
Find all positive integers n such that exists bijective g: Z/nZ -> Z/nZ with forall k=(ways_two_edges - 30) to 100, map x |-> g(x) + k x is bijective on Z/nZ

Ground_Truth.A32: \text{All positive integers } n \text{ relatively prime to } 101!

Math_Problem:
Find the number of triples of sets $(A, B, C)$ such that: (a) $A, B, C \subseteq\{1,2,3, \ldots, 8\}$. (b) $|A \cap B|=|B \cap C|=|C \cap A|=2$. (c) $|A|=|B|=|C|=4$. Here, $|S|$ denotes the number of elements in the set $S$. Instead of determining the total number of such triples of sets, simply find $m = |A \cap B \cap C|$, where $|A \cap B \cap C|$ is the size of the triple intersection derived from the structural consideration of configurations with no elements belonging to exactly two of the sets. Compute the number of ways there are to assemble $m$ red unit cubes and $25$ white unit cubes into a $3 \times 3 \times 3$ cube such that red is visible on exactly 4 faces of the larger cube. (Rotations and reflections are considered distinct.) Instead of computing the total number of such assemblies, simply find $d = w - 30$, where $w$ is the number of ways to place both red cubes on distinct edge-middle positions such that the faces visible from those positions are disjoint. Let $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ denote the set of integers considered modulo $n$ (hence $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ has $n$ elements). Find all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$, such that for each integer $k = d, d+1, \dots, 100$, the map $x \mapsto g(x) + k x$ is a bijection on $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$.

[i]Ashwin Sah and Yang Liu[/i]

Predicted_Answer.A32: All positive integers n relatively prime to 101!

Synthesised_By.A1074: Find the number of triples of sets $(A, B, C)$ such that: (a) $A, B, C \subseteq\{1,2,3, \ldots, 8\}$. (b) $|A \cap B|=|B \cap C|=|C \cap A|=2$. (c) $|A|=|B|=|C|=4$. Here, $|S|$ denotes the number of elements in the set $S$.

Synthesised_By.A1136: Compute the number of ways there are to assemble 2 red unit cubes and 25 white unit cubes into a $3 \times 3 \times 3$ cube such that red is visible on exactly 4 faces of the larger cube. (Rotations and reflections are considered distinct.)

Synthesised_By.A32:
Let $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ denote the set of integers considered modulo $n$ (hence $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ has $n$ elements). Find all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$, such that the 101 functions
\[g(x), \quad g(x) + x, \quad g(x) + 2x, \quad \dots, \quad g(x) + 100x\]
are all bijections on $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$.

[i]Ashwin Sah and Yang Liu[/i]
